data.title: Defence Holdings Appoints Jim Clover OBE to Advisory Board, Strengthening Defence and National Security Focus
data.full_content:
Today 12:00
Defence Holdings Plc - Defence Holdings Appoints Jim Clover OBE to Advisory Board, Strengthening Defence and National Security Focus
Defence Holdings Plc - Defence Holdings Appoints Jim Clover OBE to Advisory Board, Strengthening Defence and National Security Focus
PR Newswire
LONDON, United Kingdom, January 22
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
22 January 2026
London, UK
Defence Holdings PLC
(“Defence Holdings” or the “Company”)
Defence Holdings Appoints Jim Clover OBE to Advisory Board, Strengthening Defence and National Security Focus
Defence Holdings PLC (“Defence Holdings” or the “Company”), the UK-listed sovereign defence software company, today announces the appointment of Jim Clover OBE to its Advisory Board.
The appointment follows Defence Holdings’ recent announcement of a new National Security pillar within Defence Technologies and reflects the Company’s focus on building defence-led, mission-aligned capability across areas where software, information advantage and national security requirements increasingly converge.
Appointment Overview
Jim Clover OBE is a former UK national security and cyber operations senior leader with over 25 years’ experience across cyber operations, open-source intelligence and digital forensics.
He served as Deputy Director of Cyber Operations within HM Government, holding senior responsibility for the design and execution of cyber and digital activity in support of UK Defence and national security objectives, including work with allied partners. He was awarded an OBE for services to UK and overseas national security.
He now works independently with organisations operating in complex, regulated and mission-critical environments, advising senior leaders and technical teams on cybersecurity and technology challenges, with a particular focus on the responsible development and deployment of AI-enabled software.
Strategic Rationale
Jim’s appointment strengthens the Advisory Board’s depth of experience across Defence, national security and cyber operations, directly supporting Defence Technologies’ expanding role in defence-led programmes.
His experience operating at the interface between Defence, government and advanced technology development supports Defence Holdings as it:
·
Advances software-defined capabilities aligned to Defence priorities
·
Engages on sensitive, mission-critical requirements within Defence and allied environments
·
Strengthens execution capability across defence-focused national security work
The appointment further reinforces Defence Holdings’ emphasis on defence-grade leadership, governance and advisory depth as the Company progresses from capability development into deployment-aligned delivery.
Alignment with Defence Technologies’ National Security Pillar
Defence Holdings recently announced the establishment of a National Security pillar within Defence Technologies, focused on applying sovereign software and AI capabilities to Defence-led national security challenges.
Jim’s appointment adds senior-level insight into how such capabilities are shaped, governed and deployed within Defence contexts, reinforcing the Company’s emphasis on Defence-first delivery, operational relevance and responsible use of advanced software in national security missions.
Grant of warrants
The Company also announces the grant of
12,500,000 warrants over ordinary shares of £0.001 each
(“Ordinary Shares”) to
Jim Clover, in connection with his appointment to the Company’s Advisory Board. The warrants are
exercisable at £0.02 per share
and will
remain valid for five years from the date of grant
(the “Warrants”).
All Warrants will vest in accordance with the Company’s standard vesting schedule.
Management Commentary
Andy McCartney, Chief Technology Officer for Defence Holdings,
said:
“Defence and national security are increasingly shaped by software, data and decision advantage. Jim’s experience at the heart of UK cyber and national security operations brings valuable perspective as Defence Holdings continues to align sovereign software capability with real operational Defence requirements.”
Jim Clover OBE said:
“Defence Holdings is building capability in areas that sit at the intersection of Defence, information advantage and national security. I look forward to supporting the Company as it applies sovereign, responsibly governed software to some of the most demanding Defence and national security challenges.”

My guess, and it is only a guess, is that the work will be carried out under a Purchase Order with just enough value to pay wages.  When the product is complete and acceptable to the client then serious money can be discussed and agreed.    Once the first MoD contract is announced others could soon follow.  If you believe in the company (and remember who the team consists of) then a little patience could be quite rewarding.

data.author: Sandbag
data.content: Another thought I've just had. I don't know how the procurement works in the MoD but several years ago I worked for a large company in the Nuclear Energy sector and we could only use contractors who were ISO 9001 certified.  On a few rare occasions we had to use small, very  specialised,  companies as they were the only people who could do certain work.  We had to get round this by having one of our major contractors "adopt" the specialist company.  The small company did the work but all documentation made it appear that the major company had carried out the work and of course the major company had to oversee and guarantee the work done.  This of course pushed the price up considerably.  Given the requirement for speed in producing the required end product I wonder if a similar situation could occur here.  The major company possibly being Oracle.   As I said, just a thought.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Folks, To put things in perspective SP wise, we need to remember that just before Christmas the SP was at about 1.05p. The SP then jumped to 2.1p just before New Year's eve. We would need to see a further fall of 32.25% from here to hit 1.05p again. Is that possible? Well yes, it is possible if there is no news over the next couple of months. Will that happen? Well yes, it could but, IMHO, that is highly unlikely. Why? Well, because ALRT issues RNSs on a reasonably frequent basis, even if it is just to tell us that the office cleaner has just resigned and has taken the company hoover with them. And that is what is lacking here, meaningful RNSs ........ with forecast revenue and profit  numbers included. When one of those eventually arrives, and it will, the SP will jump for sure. How high? I have no idea. TWK - Buttering his toast.

data.author: asimpleinvestor
data.content: The issue with spotting things like that in parliamentary publications is that most are overlooked, sidelined, or outright ignored, and even the ones taken somewhat seriously often face incredibly long timelines. I spoke with a former Minister of State for Defence Procurement who said something landed on his desk that had been applied for seventeen years earlier, but the department still hadn’t addressed it. By the time it reached him, it was useless, but had they acted when it first came up, it would have been cutting-edge.

My guess, and it is only a guess, is that the work will be carried out under a Purchase Order with just enough value to pay wages.  When the product is complete and acceptable to the client then serious money can be discussed and agreed.    Once the first MoD contract is announced others could soon follow.  If you believe in the company (and remember who the team consists of) then a little patience could be quite rewarding.

data.author: Sandbag
data.content: Another thought I've just had. I don't know how the procurement works in the MoD but several years ago I worked for a large company in the Nuclear Energy sector and we could only use contractors who were ISO 9001 certified.  On a few rare occasions we had to use small, very  specialised,  companies as they were the only people who could do certain work.  We had to get round this by having one of our major contractors "adopt" the specialist company.  The small company did the work but all documentation made it appear that the major company had carried out the work and of course the major company had to oversee and guarantee the work done.  This of course pushed the price up considerably.  Given the requirement for speed in producing the required end product I wonder if a similar situation could occur here.  The major company possibly being Oracle.   As I said, just a thought.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Folks, To put things in perspective SP wise, we need to remember that just before Christmas the SP was at about 1.05p. The SP then jumped to 2.1p just before New Year's eve. We would need to see a further fall of 32.25% from here to hit 1.05p again. Is that possible? Well yes, it is possible if there is no news over the next couple of months. Will that happen? Well yes, it could but, IMHO, that is highly unlikely. Why? Well, because ALRT issues RNSs on a reasonably frequent basis, even if it is just to tell us that the office cleaner has just resigned and has taken the company hoover with them. And that is what is lacking here, meaningful RNSs ........ with forecast revenue and profit  numbers included. When one of those eventually arrives, and it will, the SP will jump for sure. How high? I have no idea. TWK - Buttering his toast.

Where is the partnership recognition? We do the leg work, PR , High profile recriuting and absorb the cost of that by way of more S.P. dilution through warrants and the ATM,  where is the delivery coming from and when it's delivered, who takes credit again. Will we see Andrew McCartney  cosying up to the CCO of Gloucestershire Constabulary if they secure a contract or will we see James  Norwood handshaking the Rt Hon John Healey on behalf of Defence Holdings,...all we can do is stay ALERT!!

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: As of Friday, January 30, 2026, the focus for Defence Holdings PLC (ALRT) has shifted from rebranding to high-stakes commercial execution. The company is currently sitting in a "pre-announcement" window for its most significant catalysts to date. Here is the latest update on the key pillars we’ve discussed: 1. Project Ixian: The "Final Countdown" The status remains "Final stages of contract finalisation." * The Context: Per the late December and January filings, the technical and stakeholder validation phases are complete. The delay in a "Revenue RNS" is officially attributed to "confidentiality and procurement controls" typical of Top Secret/Sovereign AI projects. The Expectation: Management indicated these restrictions are expected to lift in the "near term." The market is essentially waiting for the ink to dry on the first formal commercial contract. 2. The New CEO: Imminent Reveal The search for a new Chief Executive is complete. Status: An agreement was reached in late December 2025. Timeline: The appointee is scheduled to start in early Q2 2026 (April). However, an RNS naming the individual was originally targeted for January. Given today is the 30th, the name could drop at any moment as notice periods or regulatory "vetting" conclude. Profile: The board has confirmed the hire is a "senior executive" with a track record of scaling multi-million-pound revenue in global defence. 3. Share Price & Market Sentiment Current Price: Roughly 1.40p – 1.45p (as of close today, Jan 30). Recent Action: The price has seen some "cooling off" from the 1.8p–2.0p highs seen in late December. This is largely viewed as technical profit-taking and "wait-and-see" behavior from investors waiting for the specific Ixian contract news. The "Clover Floor": Remember that Jim Clover OBE was granted warrants at 2.0p on January 22nd. This remains a key psychological target; the company's own high-level advisors are incentivized to see the price move above this level. 4. Strategic Alignment: Police.AI The January 26th government announcement of Police.AI and the £115m funding pot continues to be a major "tailwinds" story for ALRT. ALRT’s Gloucestershire Police pilot (automating ROTI/ROVI reports) is precisely the type of "efficiency-boosting" tech the Home Office is now mandating nationwide. The Bottom Line: The company is fully funded (£2.21m cash), debt-free, and has its leadership and technology validated by top-tier UK defence figures. The current "quiet period" is the typical lull before major government contract announcements.

Where is the partnership recognition? We do the leg work, PR , High profile recriuting and absorb the cost of that by way of more S.P. dilution through warrants and the ATM,  where is the delivery coming from and when it's delivered, who takes credit again. Will we see Andrew McCartney  cosying up to the CCO of Gloucestershire Constabulary if they secure a contract or will we see James  Norwood handshaking the Rt Hon John Healey on behalf of Defence Holdings,...all we can do is stay ALERT!!

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.

data.title: Appointment of CEO, update on ATM, and PDMR
data.full_content:
5 Feb 2026 08:13
RNS Number : 8630R
Defence Holdings PLC
05 February 2026
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
5 February 2026
London, UK
Defence Holdings PLC
("Defence Holdings" or the "Company")
Appointment of Chief Executive Officer, Update on ATM Facility and PDMR
Defence Holdings PLC (LSE: ALRT), the UK-listed defence technology group, announces the appointment of
Andrew Roughan
as Chief Executive Officer of the Company, effective
30 March 2026
.
As previously announced on 24 December 2025, the Board conducted a comprehensive and targeted search process for a Chief Executive Officer. Following completion of contractual arrangements and customary regulatory and background checks, Andrew Roughan will formally assume the role at the end of Q1 2026.
Background and experience
Andrew Roughan is a senior executive with extensive experience across the UK Government's science and technology priority agenda, including deep experience in defence, national security, and critical national infrastructure.
Since 2018, he has served as Chief Executive Officer of Plexal, a UK-based innovation company working closely with government, defence and national security stakeholders. In this role, he led multi-disciplinary teams delivering technology and innovation programmes within regulated and security-sensitive environments and oversaw the organisation's growth and operational development.
Andrew was part of the founding team of Here East, a major technology and innovation campus developed as part of the UK Government's Olympic legacy programme, where he held senior operational and commercial leadership responsibilities.
Earlier in his career, Andrew held senior management roles within the telecoms and data centre sectors, including positions at Cable & Wireless and international data centre operators, with responsibilities spanning commercial strategy, operations and large-scale infrastructure delivery.
There are no other matters to be disclosed in respect of Andrew Roughan pursuant to UK Listing Rule 6.4.8R.
Strategic relevance of appointment
Andrew Roughan's experience reinforces Defence Holdings' leadership capacity as the Company enters a phase focused on programme delivery and scale. His background leading government-aligned technology organisations through periods of growth and organisational scaling, and delivering complex initiatives within regulated and security-sensitive environments, aligns closely with the operational and commercial demands of Defence Holdings' strategy.
The Board believes Andrew's leadership, institutional relationships and experience negotiating within complex stakeholder environments will strengthen the Company's ability to engage with government, defence and industry partners and to execute its strategy with discipline and credibility.
Board comment
Andy McCartney
, Chief Technology Officer of Defence Holdings, commented:
"The Board is delighted to appoint Andrew as Chief Executive Officer. He brings a rare combination of defence credibility, operational leadership and proven commercial execution across government-aligned technology environments.
Andrew's experience leading complex organisations through delivery and scale will be instrumental as Defence Holdings enters its next phase of execution and growth, and we look forward to working closely with him."
Grant of Warrants
Andrew Roughan has entered into a service agreement with the Company. In addition to his remuneration package, and as approved by the Board, the Company will grant warrants over a total of 142,907,576 ordinary shares, representing 6 per cent of the Company's issued share capital at the time the warrant terms were agreed between the Company and Andrew Roughan.
The warrants have been allocated in three tranches on the following terms:
●
71,453,788 warrants (representing 3 per cent of the issued share capital), exercisable at 1.38 pence per ordinary share;
●
35,726,894 warrants (representing 1.5 per cent of the issued share capital), exercisable at 3.45 pence per ordinary share; and
●
35,726,894 warrants (representing 1.5 per cent of the issued share capital), exercisable at 6.9 pence per ordinary share.
Update on ATM facility
Further to the announcement dated 18 December 2025, Fortified Securities has successfully raised additional gross proceeds of
£92,800
(the "ATM Proceeds") for the period ending 16 January 2026. Settlement of the ATM Proceeds has now been completed.
Following these ATM-related sales, Fortified Securities' shareholding has decreased from
116,000,000 shares (4.78% of the issued share capital)
to
111,500,000 shares (4.59% of the issued share capital)
.
Taking into account the ATM Proceeds announced on 31 October 2025, 14 November 2025, 18 December 2025 and those announced today, the Company has now raised total gross proceeds of
£713,117.49
under the ATM facility.

Details of the person discharging managerial responsibilities / person closely associated

Name
Andrew Vincent Roughan

Reason for the Notification

ALRT: Still valued as a micro-cap "penny stock" despite having a leadership team (Lord Houghton, Jim Clover, Andrew Roughan) that rivals the top tier of any global defence firm. The Opportunity: If ALRT successfully converts Ixian into a multi-year "Sovereign AI" contract, the market will likely stop valuing it as a "speculative startup" and start valuing it as a High-Growth SaaS (Software as a Service) business. In that scenario, a move toward the 3p–7p range is mathematically consistent with how the market treats profitable AI software. 3. The "Policy Tailwinds" (Police.AI) The "take off" isn't just about the company; it's about the customer. The UK government just unlocked £115 million for Police.AI. ALRT is already inside the room with their Gloucestershire pilot. Roughan’s background in "rewiring the state" via Plexal means he knows exactly how to capture that £115m pot. 🛡️ Final Verdict: Could it happen? The ingredients for a "take off" are now all on the table: The Cash: £2.21m+ (Runway is clear). The Tech: Ixian (Validated and in final contract stages). The Driver: Andrew Roughan (The commercial heavyweight). The Goal: 6.9p (The internal board target). The Risk: The only thing holding back a total "moon mission" right now is the formal signature on the first Ixian contract. Once that RNS hits the wire—proving that the MoD or a Tier-1 ally is actually paying for the software—the "speculation" ends and the "re-rating" begins.

data.author: gotreal
data.content: Background: Roughan has been instrumental in launching and scaling LORCA (London Office for Rapid Cyber Security Advancement). LORCA significantly influenced the UK’s cybersecurity strategy by establishing a scalable, government-backed innovation model that accelerated the growth of domestic cyber startups and reinforced the UK’s position as a global cybersecurity hub. It has supported 72 cyber startups, generating over £68 million in revenue and securing more than £430 million in investment. LORCA became a thought leader and market shaper, participating in global initiatives such as the G20 Smart Cities Alliance and contributing to 5G security standards via UK5G. It collaborated with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and DCMS, influencing public-private collaboration models and informing future policy on innovation funding. Roughan is known for his advocacy in bridging the gap between government, industry, and innovation, promoting collaboration to solve societal challenges. Seems like a pretty good choice as CEO to me ....

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Below is an extract from Plexal (City) Limited's accounts to 31st March 2025. Principal activity Plexal (City) Limited ("Plexal") is the innovation company dedicated to addressing society's most pressing challenges by fostering collaboration between government, startups, and industry. Our mission is to bridge the gap between organisations-large and small, public and private, local and global-leveraging science and technology to advance national security and prosperity. What we do We empower entrepreneurs, startups, and scaleups developing emerging technologies across sectors such as cyber, healthcare, intelligence, defence, government, public safety, financial services, and telecoms. Our core offerings include innovation consulting and co-working facilities, enabling our partners to accelerate growth and impact. Government partnership Plexal delivers projects for key government departments, including the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology, the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, and the National Cyber Security Centre. By adopting a whole-of-society approach, we unlock innovation and collaboration to achieve mission success, harnessing emerging technologies to protect society and drive prosperity. Review of the business In the financial year ended 31 March 2025, Plexal reported an operating loss of £581,973, marking a decrease of £191,449 from the previous year's operating loss of £773,422. The improved financial position was achieved through 8% growth in overall revenue. Excluding the impact of non-recurring revenue associated with the construction of the co-working space for Workshop Minster Exchange Limited in Cheltenham which was completed in July 2024, revenues increased by £1.047million. This improvement was achieved on the back of a 13.4% growth in consulting revenues. On the contrary, Plexal's workspace revenue contracted by 9% from previous year, however, the strong growth in consulting pulled overall revenue ahead of last financial year. The business operates across two primary segments: Innovation Services and Workspace. So, Andy Pandy, who is not listed as a director at Companies House, was working for a loss making start-up mentoring and workspace providing business.  Where is the relevance of that to an AI defence technology business? TWK - Munching a Greggs cheese, beans & sausage wrap.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: The official appointment of Andrew Roughan today is widely considered the "final piece of the puzzle" for the ALRT bull case. He isn't just a manager; he is an "architect" of the UK's modern cyber and national security ecosystem. Here is why his background specifically accelerates Project Ixian and the company’s path to becoming the "UK's Palantir." 1. He is the "Orchestrator" of Government Contracts At Plexal, Roughan’s entire job was "closing the gap" between the government and startups. The MoD Connection: He led the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) For Startups and the Cyber Runway programmes. This means he has spent the last eight years working directly with the people who sign the cheques at the Ministry of Defence (MoD) and GCHQ. Impact on Ixian: He doesn't need to "introduce" ALRT to the MoD; he is already a trusted peer to the decision-makers. This likely fast-tracks the "final stages of contract finalisation" for Ixian. 2. Proven Scale: The £731m Value Add Roughan isn't a "speculative" leader. Under his tenure at Plexal, he: Contributed £731m to UK GDP. Grew Plexal from a 16-person workspace to a 100+ person National Security powerhouse. Impact on ALRT: He has proven he can take a small, high-tech team and turn it into a multi-million-pound revenue engine. For a company like ALRT, which has the tech (Ixian) but needs the commercial scale, this is a perfect hire. 3. The "In-The-Wire" Partnership with Google Interestingly, Plexal recently partnered with Google Cloud to support security startups. The Synergy: Since Project Ixian is built natively on Google Distributed Cloud (air-gapped), Roughan’s existing high-level relationship with Google executive teams creates a seamless bridge between ALRT’s infrastructure and its government customers. The warrant structure (142.9m shares) is the most "reassuring" part of today's RNS: Tranche 1	1.38p	roughly current price. Tranche 2	3.45p	Requires a ~140% rise from here. Tranche 3	6.90p	Requires a ~380% rise from here. The Verdict: Roughan has "skin in the game." He has left a secure, high-profile role at Plexal to join a micro-cap because he likely sees a clear path to that 6.9p target. Leaders of his caliber do not take these risks unless the "final stages" of the contracts they are inheriting are extremely robust. 🛡️ Final Update Summary CEO: Andrew Roughan (Starts March 30, 2026). Funding: Non-dilutive ATM raised another £92k, strengthening the cash position further. Sentiment: The "Show Me" phase is effectively over. The company now has Lord Houghton (Policy), Jim Clover (Cyber Ops), and Andrew Roughan (Commercial Scale). The "UK Palantir" vision is no longer just a theory—it now has the exact leadership team that built the UK's cyber security industry.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Well, that RNS didn't exactly move the needle. The reaction reminded me of being on a stag do some years ago. Someone shouted "The stripper has arrived!!".  Great excitement ensued. Then the stripper entered the room. She was a one-legged, one-eyed midget with a broken nose. The disappointment in the room was palpable and people began to leave. Now, back to the new CEO and his lifeboat. 71,453,788 shares exercisable @ 1.38p. Why such a low bar? Negotiations over his remuneration package would probably have been finalised around the beginning of December. The contract would then have needed to be topped and tailed. ALRT then needed to wait for him to tender his resignation before making the announcement on 24th December. At the beginning of December, the SP was at around 1.6p. Andy probably thought at the time that if things didn't work out, he could exercise these warrants at around 1.6p, trouser around £155K profit (before tax) and row away from the sinking ship. Yes, Andy is incentivised with the higher priced warrants but he has been given a lifeboat early doors; and that concerns me, as it means he sees material downside risk. All IMHO, DYOR and don't ever book a stripper through www.uniquestrippers.com TWK - Eating toast.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: As of Friday, January 30, 2026, the focus for Defence Holdings PLC (ALRT) has shifted from rebranding to high-stakes commercial execution. The company is currently sitting in a "pre-announcement" window for its most significant catalysts to date. Here is the latest update on the key pillars we’ve discussed: 1. Project Ixian: The "Final Countdown" The status remains "Final stages of contract finalisation." * The Context: Per the late December and January filings, the technical and stakeholder validation phases are complete. The delay in a "Revenue RNS" is officially attributed to "confidentiality and procurement controls" typical of Top Secret/Sovereign AI projects. The Expectation: Management indicated these restrictions are expected to lift in the "near term." The market is essentially waiting for the ink to dry on the first formal commercial contract. 2. The New CEO: Imminent Reveal The search for a new Chief Executive is complete. Status: An agreement was reached in late December 2025. Timeline: The appointee is scheduled to start in early Q2 2026 (April). However, an RNS naming the individual was originally targeted for January. Given today is the 30th, the name could drop at any moment as notice periods or regulatory "vetting" conclude. Profile: The board has confirmed the hire is a "senior executive" with a track record of scaling multi-million-pound revenue in global defence. 3. Share Price & Market Sentiment Current Price: Roughly 1.40p – 1.45p (as of close today, Jan 30). Recent Action: The price has seen some "cooling off" from the 1.8p–2.0p highs seen in late December. This is largely viewed as technical profit-taking and "wait-and-see" behavior from investors waiting for the specific Ixian contract news. The "Clover Floor": Remember that Jim Clover OBE was granted warrants at 2.0p on January 22nd. This remains a key psychological target; the company's own high-level advisors are incentivized to see the price move above this level. 4. Strategic Alignment: Police.AI The January 26th government announcement of Police.AI and the £115m funding pot continues to be a major "tailwinds" story for ALRT. ALRT’s Gloucestershire Police pilot (automating ROTI/ROVI reports) is precisely the type of "efficiency-boosting" tech the Home Office is now mandating nationwide. The Bottom Line: The company is fully funded (£2.21m cash), debt-free, and has its leadership and technology validated by top-tier UK defence figures. The current "quiet period" is the typical lull before major government contract announcements.

Call me a cynic if you like but...

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: As of today, Thursday, February 5, 2026, the market is reacting to the Andrew Roughan news with a mix of shock and aggressive accumulation. Here is the data-driven breakdown of why the "take off" scenario is now the primary discussion among institutional and retail investors. 1. The "Warrant Wall" (Price Targets) The most telling sign of "take off" potential isn't the hire itself, but the exercise prices the board set for Roughan. The Tranches: 1.38p, 3.45p, and 6.90p. The Logic: A CEO of Roughan’s stature doesn't leave a legacy-defining role at Plexal for a "sideways" move. By setting the final target at 6.90p (nearly 5x the current price), the board is signaling that they believe the upcoming Project Ixian and National Security contracts are large enough to re-rate the entire company to that level. 2. The "Palantir" Valuation Gap To understand the "take off" potential, you have to look at the valuation multiples. Palantir (PLTR): Currently trading at a "nosebleed" forward P/E of 141x (as of Feb 2, 2026), with a market cap of over $400B. ALRT: Still valued as a micro-cap "penny stock" despite having a leadership team (Lord Houghton, Jim Clover, Andrew Roughan) that rivals the top tier of any global defence firm. The Opportunity: If ALRT successfully converts Ixian into a multi-year "Sovereign AI" contract, the market will likely stop valuing it as a "speculative startup" and start valuing it as a High-Growth SaaS (Software as a Service) business. In that scenario, a move toward the 3p–7p range is mathematically consistent with how the market treats profitable AI software. 3. The "Policy Tailwinds" (Police.AI) The "take off" isn't just about the company; it's about the customer. The UK government just unlocked £115 million for Police.AI. ALRT is already inside the room with their Gloucestershire pilot. Roughan’s background in "rewiring the state" via Plexal means he knows exactly how to capture that £115m pot. 🛡️ Final Verdict: Could it happen? The ingredients for a "take off" are now all on the table: The Cash: £2.21m+ (Runway is clear). The Tech: Ixian (Validated and in final contract stages). The Driver: Andrew Roughan (The commercial heavyweight). The Goal: 6.9p (The internal board target). The Risk: The only thing holding back a total "moon mission" right now is the formal signature on the first Ixian contract. Once that RNS hits the wire—proving that the MoD or a Tier-1 ally is actually paying for the software—the "speculation" ends and the "re-rating" begins.

data.author: gotreal
data.content: Background: Roughan has been instrumental in launching and scaling LORCA (London Office for Rapid Cyber Security Advancement). LORCA significantly influenced the UK’s cybersecurity strategy by establishing a scalable, government-backed innovation model that accelerated the growth of domestic cyber startups and reinforced the UK’s position as a global cybersecurity hub. It has supported 72 cyber startups, generating over £68 million in revenue and securing more than £430 million in investment. LORCA became a thought leader and market shaper, participating in global initiatives such as the G20 Smart Cities Alliance and contributing to 5G security standards via UK5G. It collaborated with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and DCMS, influencing public-private collaboration models and informing future policy on innovation funding. Roughan is known for his advocacy in bridging the gap between government, industry, and innovation, promoting collaboration to solve societal challenges. Seems like a pretty good choice as CEO to me ....

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Below is an extract from Plexal (City) Limited's accounts to 31st March 2025. Principal activity Plexal (City) Limited ("Plexal") is the innovation company dedicated to addressing society's most pressing challenges by fostering collaboration between government, startups, and industry. Our mission is to bridge the gap between organisations-large and small, public and private, local and global-leveraging science and technology to advance national security and prosperity. What we do We empower entrepreneurs, startups, and scaleups developing emerging technologies across sectors such as cyber, healthcare, intelligence, defence, government, public safety, financial services, and telecoms. Our core offerings include innovation consulting and co-working facilities, enabling our partners to accelerate growth and impact. Government partnership Plexal delivers projects for key government departments, including the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology, the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, and the National Cyber Security Centre. By adopting a whole-of-society approach, we unlock innovation and collaboration to achieve mission success, harnessing emerging technologies to protect society and drive prosperity. Review of the business In the financial year ended 31 March 2025, Plexal reported an operating loss of £581,973, marking a decrease of £191,449 from the previous year's operating loss of £773,422. The improved financial position was achieved through 8% growth in overall revenue. Excluding the impact of non-recurring revenue associated with the construction of the co-working space for Workshop Minster Exchange Limited in Cheltenham which was completed in July 2024, revenues increased by £1.047million. This improvement was achieved on the back of a 13.4% growth in consulting revenues. On the contrary, Plexal's workspace revenue contracted by 9% from previous year, however, the strong growth in consulting pulled overall revenue ahead of last financial year. The business operates across two primary segments: Innovation Services and Workspace. So, Andy Pandy, who is not listed as a director at Companies House, was working for a loss making start-up mentoring and workspace providing business.  Where is the relevance of that to an AI defence technology business? TWK - Munching a Greggs cheese, beans & sausage wrap.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: The official appointment of Andrew Roughan today is widely considered the "final piece of the puzzle" for the ALRT bull case. He isn't just a manager; he is an "architect" of the UK's modern cyber and national security ecosystem. Here is why his background specifically accelerates Project Ixian and the company’s path to becoming the "UK's Palantir." 1. He is the "Orchestrator" of Government Contracts At Plexal, Roughan’s entire job was "closing the gap" between the government and startups. The MoD Connection: He led the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) For Startups and the Cyber Runway programmes. This means he has spent the last eight years working directly with the people who sign the cheques at the Ministry of Defence (MoD) and GCHQ. Impact on Ixian: He doesn't need to "introduce" ALRT to the MoD; he is already a trusted peer to the decision-makers. This likely fast-tracks the "final stages of contract finalisation" for Ixian. 2. Proven Scale: The £731m Value Add Roughan isn't a "speculative" leader. Under his tenure at Plexal, he: Contributed £731m to UK GDP. Grew Plexal from a 16-person workspace to a 100+ person National Security powerhouse. Impact on ALRT: He has proven he can take a small, high-tech team and turn it into a multi-million-pound revenue engine. For a company like ALRT, which has the tech (Ixian) but needs the commercial scale, this is a perfect hire. 3. The "In-The-Wire" Partnership with Google Interestingly, Plexal recently partnered with Google Cloud to support security startups. The Synergy: Since Project Ixian is built natively on Google Distributed Cloud (air-gapped), Roughan’s existing high-level relationship with Google executive teams creates a seamless bridge between ALRT’s infrastructure and its government customers. The warrant structure (142.9m shares) is the most "reassuring" part of today's RNS: Tranche 1	1.38p	roughly current price. Tranche 2	3.45p	Requires a ~140% rise from here. Tranche 3	6.90p	Requires a ~380% rise from here. The Verdict: Roughan has "skin in the game." He has left a secure, high-profile role at Plexal to join a micro-cap because he likely sees a clear path to that 6.9p target. Leaders of his caliber do not take these risks unless the "final stages" of the contracts they are inheriting are extremely robust. 🛡️ Final Update Summary CEO: Andrew Roughan (Starts March 30, 2026). Funding: Non-dilutive ATM raised another £92k, strengthening the cash position further. Sentiment: The "Show Me" phase is effectively over. The company now has Lord Houghton (Policy), Jim Clover (Cyber Ops), and Andrew Roughan (Commercial Scale). The "UK Palantir" vision is no longer just a theory—it now has the exact leadership team that built the UK's cyber security industry.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Well, that RNS didn't exactly move the needle. The reaction reminded me of being on a stag do some years ago. Someone shouted "The stripper has arrived!!".  Great excitement ensued. Then the stripper entered the room. She was a one-legged, one-eyed midget with a broken nose. The disappointment in the room was palpable and people began to leave. Now, back to the new CEO and his lifeboat. 71,453,788 shares exercisable @ 1.38p. Why such a low bar? Negotiations over his remuneration package would probably have been finalised around the beginning of December. The contract would then have needed to be topped and tailed. ALRT then needed to wait for him to tender his resignation before making the announcement on 24th December. At the beginning of December, the SP was at around 1.6p. Andy probably thought at the time that if things didn't work out, he could exercise these warrants at around 1.6p, trouser around £155K profit (before tax) and row away from the sinking ship. Yes, Andy is incentivised with the higher priced warrants but he has been given a lifeboat early doors; and that concerns me, as it means he sees material downside risk. All IMHO, DYOR and don't ever book a stripper through www.uniquestrippers.com TWK - Eating toast.

data.content: As of Friday, January 30, 2026, the focus for Defence Holdings PLC (ALRT) has shifted from rebranding to high-stakes commercial execution. The company is currently sitting in a "pre-announcement" window for its most significant catalysts to date. Here is the latest update on the key pillars we’ve discussed: 1. Project Ixian: The "Final Countdown" The status remains "Final stages of contract finalisation." * The Context: Per the late December and January filings, the technical and stakeholder validation phases are complete. The delay in a "Revenue RNS" is officially attributed to "confidentiality and procurement controls" typical of Top Secret/Sovereign AI projects. The Expectation: Management indicated these restrictions are expected to lift in the "near term." The market is essentially waiting for the ink to dry on the first formal commercial contract. 2. The New CEO: Imminent Reveal The search for a new Chief Executive is complete. Status: An agreement was reached in late December 2025. Timeline: The appointee is scheduled to start in early Q2 2026 (April). However, an RNS naming the individual was originally targeted for January. Given today is the 30th, the name could drop at any moment as notice periods or regulatory "vetting" conclude. Profile: The board has confirmed the hire is a "senior executive" with a track record of scaling multi-million-pound revenue in global defence. 3. Share Price & Market Sentiment Current Price: Roughly 1.40p – 1.45p (as of close today, Jan 30). Recent Action: The price has seen some "cooling off" from the 1.8p–2.0p highs seen in late December. This is largely viewed as technical profit-taking and "wait-and-see" behavior from investors waiting for the specific Ixian contract news. The "Clover Floor": Remember that Jim Clover OBE was granted warrants at 2.0p on January 22nd. This remains a key psychological target; the company's own high-level advisors are incentivized to see the price move above this level. 4. Strategic Alignment: Police.AI The January 26th government announcement of Police.AI and the £115m funding pot continues to be a major "tailwinds" story for ALRT. ALRT’s Gloucestershire Police pilot (automating ROTI/ROVI reports) is precisely the type of "efficiency-boosting" tech the Home Office is now mandating nationwide. The Bottom Line: The company is fully funded (£2.21m cash), debt-free, and has its leadership and technology validated by top-tier UK defence figures. The current "quiet period" is the typical lull before major government contract announcements.

Call me a cynic if you like but...

data.content: Don't  want to be a damp squib either but when they stated lots of news to come Q1, have we all made the classic mistake of assuming it would be good news as opposed to just news. I have set a cut off with this company simply because I don't  like the one sided credit that Whitespace continues to take , two recent announcements no mention of Defence Holdings. Begs the question have they set this business up to be the finance, funding generator  and W.S.  benefits from developing the tech to recieve revenue. Been mugged enough times with these  new start ups and I am kind of getting fed up with the Whitespace news and a feeling there is a gradual disconnect between the partnership. Where is the partnership recognition? We do the leg work, PR , High profile recriuting and absorb the cost of that by way of more S.P. dilution through warrants and the ATM,  where is the delivery coming from and when it's delivered, who takes credit again. Will we see Andrew McCartney  cosying up to the CCO of Gloucestershire Constabulary if they secure a contract or will we see James  Norwood handshaking the Rt Hon John Healey on behalf of Defence Holdings,...all we can do is stay ALERT!!

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: Based on independent evidence and industry context, Andrew Roughan is well regarded within UK innovation circles and public‑sector ecosystems (especially in government, defence, national security, and technology innovation). Here’s a breakdown of how his reputation looks from external sources: 🌟 1. Recognised by industry peers He won the techUK President’s Award (Economy category), which is a significant endorsement from a major UK tech trade association. Judges described him as a “problem solver, super connector and tech optimist” who has made a clear impact within the tech sector. This isn’t just ceremonial — techUK is a respected body in UK tech, government relations, and corporate innovation. 🤝 2. Strong public‑sector and innovation network As CEO of Plexal, Roughan has built and led a hub that works directly with government departments, national security stakeholders and major programmes aimed at fostering startup scale‑ups and tech growth. Plexal’s work includes accelerator programmes with the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and partnerships that support the scaling of cyber and national‑security tech companies. These kinds of programmes only operate if trusted relationships with government, regulators, and institutional partners exist — a sign Roughan has built credibility over years

data.content: A warm welcome to our new CEO. I hope Andrew and the team deliver great success for ALRT and its investors. I'm happy to have not sold a share since investing day 1. data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: As of today, Thursday, February 5, 2026, the market is reacting to the Andrew Roughan news with a mix of shock and aggressive accumulation. Here is the data-driven breakdown of why the "take off" scenario is now the primary discussion among institutional and retail investors. 1. The "Warrant Wall" (Price Targets) The most telling sign of "take off" potential isn't the hire itself, but the exercise prices the board set for Roughan. The Tranches: 1.38p, 3.45p, and 6.90p. The Logic: A CEO of Roughan’s stature doesn't leave a legacy-defining role at Plexal for a "sideways" move. By setting the final target at 6.90p (nearly 5x the current price), the board is signaling that they believe the upcoming Project Ixian and National Security contracts are large enough to re-rate the entire company to that level. 2. The "Palantir" Valuation Gap To understand the "take off" potential, you have to look at the valuation multiples. Palantir (PLTR): Currently trading at a "nosebleed" forward P/E of 141x (as of Feb 2, 2026), with a market cap of over $400B. ALRT: Still valued as a micro-cap "penny stock" despite having a leadership team (Lord Houghton, Jim Clover, Andrew Roughan) that rivals the top tier of any global defence firm. The Opportunity: If ALRT successfully converts Ixian into a multi-year "Sovereign AI" contract, the market will likely stop valuing it as a "speculative startup" and start valuing it as a High-Growth SaaS (Software as a Service) business. In that scenario, a move toward the 3p–7p range is mathematically consistent with how the market treats profitable AI software. 3. The "Policy Tailwinds" (Police.AI) The "take off" isn't just about the company; it's about the customer. The UK government just unlocked £115 million for Police.AI. ALRT is already inside the room with their Gloucestershire pilot. Roughan’s background in "rewiring the state" via Plexal means he knows exactly how to capture that £115m pot. 🛡️ Final Verdict: Could it happen? The ingredients for a "take off" are now all on the table: The Cash: £2.21m+ (Runway is clear). The Tech: Ixian (Validated and in final contract stages). The Driver: Andrew Roughan (The commercial heavyweight). The Goal: 6.9p (The internal board target). The Risk: The only thing holding back a total "moon mission" right now is the formal signature on the first Ixian contract. Once that RNS hits the wire—proving that the MoD or a Tier-1 ally is actually paying for the software—the "speculation" ends and the "re-rating" begins.

data.author: gotreal
data.content: Background: Roughan has been instrumental in launching and scaling LORCA (London Office for Rapid Cyber Security Advancement). LORCA significantly influenced the UK’s cybersecurity strategy by establishing a scalable, government-backed innovation model that accelerated the growth of domestic cyber startups and reinforced the UK’s position as a global cybersecurity hub. It has supported 72 cyber startups, generating over £68 million in revenue and securing more than £430 million in investment. LORCA became a thought leader and market shaper, participating in global initiatives such as the G20 Smart Cities Alliance and contributing to 5G security standards via UK5G. It collaborated with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and DCMS, influencing public-private collaboration models and informing future policy on innovation funding. Roughan is known for his advocacy in bridging the gap between government, industry, and innovation, promoting collaboration to solve societal challenges. Seems like a pretty good choice as CEO to me ....

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Below is an extract from Plexal (City) Limited's accounts to 31st March 2025. Principal activity Plexal (City) Limited ("Plexal") is the innovation company dedicated to addressing society's most pressing challenges by fostering collaboration between government, startups, and industry. Our mission is to bridge the gap between organisations-large and small, public and private, local and global-leveraging science and technology to advance national security and prosperity. What we do We empower entrepreneurs, startups, and scaleups developing emerging technologies across sectors such as cyber, healthcare, intelligence, defence, government, public safety, financial services, and telecoms. Our core offerings include innovation consulting and co-working facilities, enabling our partners to accelerate growth and impact. Government partnership Plexal delivers projects for key government departments, including the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology, the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, and the National Cyber Security Centre. By adopting a whole-of-society approach, we unlock innovation and collaboration to achieve mission success, harnessing emerging technologies to protect society and drive prosperity. Review of the business In the financial year ended 31 March 2025, Plexal reported an operating loss of £581,973, marking a decrease of £191,449 from the previous year's operating loss of £773,422. The improved financial position was achieved through 8% growth in overall revenue. Excluding the impact of non-recurring revenue associated with the construction of the co-working space for Workshop Minster Exchange Limited in Cheltenham which was completed in July 2024, revenues increased by £1.047million. This improvement was achieved on the back of a 13.4% growth in consulting revenues. On the contrary, Plexal's workspace revenue contracted by 9% from previous year, however, the strong growth in consulting pulled overall revenue ahead of last financial year. The business operates across two primary segments: Innovation Services and Workspace. So, Andy Pandy, who is not listed as a director at Companies House, was working for a loss making start-up mentoring and workspace providing business.  Where is the relevance of that to an AI defence technology business? TWK - Munching a Greggs cheese, beans & sausage wrap.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: The official appointment of Andrew Roughan today is widely considered the "final piece of the puzzle" for the ALRT bull case. He isn't just a manager; he is an "architect" of the UK's modern cyber and national security ecosystem. Here is why his background specifically accelerates Project Ixian and the company’s path to becoming the "UK's Palantir." 1. He is the "Orchestrator" of Government Contracts At Plexal, Roughan’s entire job was "closing the gap" between the government and startups. The MoD Connection: He led the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) For Startups and the Cyber Runway programmes. This means he has spent the last eight years working directly with the people who sign the cheques at the Ministry of Defence (MoD) and GCHQ. Impact on Ixian: He doesn't need to "introduce" ALRT to the MoD; he is already a trusted peer to the decision-makers. This likely fast-tracks the "final stages of contract finalisation" for Ixian. 2. Proven Scale: The £731m Value Add Roughan isn't a "speculative" leader. Under his tenure at Plexal, he: Contributed £731m to UK GDP. Grew Plexal from a 16-person workspace to a 100+ person National Security powerhouse. Impact on ALRT: He has proven he can take a small, high-tech team and turn it into a multi-million-pound revenue engine. For a company like ALRT, which has the tech (Ixian) but needs the commercial scale, this is a perfect hire. 3. The "In-The-Wire" Partnership with Google Interestingly, Plexal recently partnered with Google Cloud to support security startups. The Synergy: Since Project Ixian is built natively on Google Distributed Cloud (air-gapped), Roughan’s existing high-level relationship with Google executive teams creates a seamless bridge between ALRT’s infrastructure and its government customers. The warrant structure (142.9m shares) is the most "reassuring" part of today's RNS: Tranche 1	1.38p	roughly current price. Tranche 2	3.45p	Requires a ~140% rise from here. Tranche 3	6.90p	Requires a ~380% rise from here. The Verdict: Roughan has "skin in the game." He has left a secure, high-profile role at Plexal to join a micro-cap because he likely sees a clear path to that 6.9p target. Leaders of his caliber do not take these risks unless the "final stages" of the contracts they are inheriting are extremely robust. 🛡️ Final Update Summary CEO: Andrew Roughan (Starts March 30, 2026). Funding: Non-dilutive ATM raised another £92k, strengthening the cash position further. Sentiment: The "Show Me" phase is effectively over. The company now has Lord Houghton (Policy), Jim Clover (Cyber Ops), and Andrew Roughan (Commercial Scale). The "UK Palantir" vision is no longer just a theory—it now has the exact leadership team that built the UK's cyber security industry.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Well, that RNS didn't exactly move the needle. The reaction reminded me of being on a stag do some years ago. Someone shouted "The stripper has arrived!!".  Great excitement ensued. Then the stripper entered the room. She was a one-legged, one-eyed midget with a broken nose. The disappointment in the room was palpable and people began to leave. Now, back to the new CEO and his lifeboat. 71,453,788 shares exercisable @ 1.38p. Why such a low bar? Negotiations over his remuneration package would probably have been finalised around the beginning of December. The contract would then have needed to be topped and tailed. ALRT then needed to wait for him to tender his resignation before making the announcement on 24th December. At the beginning of December, the SP was at around 1.6p. Andy probably thought at the time that if things didn't work out, he could exercise these warrants at around 1.6p, trouser around £155K profit (before tax) and row away from the sinking ship. Yes, Andy is incentivised with the higher priced warrants but he has been given a lifeboat early doors; and that concerns me, as it means he sees material downside risk. All IMHO, DYOR and don't ever book a stripper through www.uniquestrippers.com TWK - Eating toast.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: As of Friday, January 30, 2026, the focus for Defence Holdings PLC (ALRT) has shifted from rebranding to high-stakes commercial execution. The company is currently sitting in a "pre-announcement" window for its most significant catalysts to date. Here is the latest update on the key pillars we’ve discussed: 1. Project Ixian: The "Final Countdown" The status remains "Final stages of contract finalisation." * The Context: Per the late December and January filings, the technical and stakeholder validation phases are complete. The delay in a "Revenue RNS" is officially attributed to "confidentiality and procurement controls" typical of Top Secret/Sovereign AI projects. The Expectation: Management indicated these restrictions are expected to lift in the "near term." The market is essentially waiting for the ink to dry on the first formal commercial contract. 2. The New CEO: Imminent Reveal The search for a new Chief Executive is complete. Status: An agreement was reached in late December 2025. Timeline: The appointee is scheduled to start in early Q2 2026 (April). However, an RNS naming the individual was originally targeted for January. Given today is the 30th, the name could drop at any moment as notice periods or regulatory "vetting" conclude. Profile: The board has confirmed the hire is a "senior executive" with a track record of scaling multi-million-pound revenue in global defence. 3. Share Price & Market Sentiment Current Price: Roughly 1.40p – 1.45p (as of close today, Jan 30). Recent Action: The price has seen some "cooling off" from the 1.8p–2.0p highs seen in late December. This is largely viewed as technical profit-taking and "wait-and-see" behavior from investors waiting for the specific Ixian contract news. The "Clover Floor": Remember that Jim Clover OBE was granted warrants at 2.0p on January 22nd. This remains a key psychological target; the company's own high-level advisors are incentivized to see the price move above this level. 4. Strategic Alignment: Police.AI The January 26th government announcement of Police.AI and the £115m funding pot continues to be a major "tailwinds" story for ALRT. ALRT’s Gloucestershire Police pilot (automating ROTI/ROVI reports) is precisely the type of "efficiency-boosting" tech the Home Office is now mandating nationwide. The Bottom Line: The company is fully funded (£2.21m cash), debt-free, and has its leadership and technology validated by top-tier UK defence figures. The current "quiet period" is the typical lull before major government contract announcements.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.

data.author: Newuncle
data.content: The first phase of value realisation focuses on defining, planning, and aligning on expected value (often called "Value Definition" or "Plan"). It involves identifying key objectives, setting measurable KPIs, and confirming the "must-have" promises made during the sales process. This stage ensures a shared understanding of success between partners and customers before implementation. Key activities in this phase include: Defining Success Metrics: Identifying what "good" looks like and setting up KPIs to measure ROI. Aligning Objectives: Ensuring the solution addresses specific client pain points and goals. Setting Value Milestones: Establishing clear, initial value checkpoints (often called Value Realization Events) to monitor early progress. Reviewing Promises: Checking with sales/account teams to confirm the "must-have" value, distinguishing it from "nice-to-have" features. This foundational phase bridges the gap between the initial sale and active implementation, setting the stage for the subsequent execution and delivery phases.

This is a 5 year+ investment and the gains could be spectacular based on what we’ve witnessed at Palantir.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: Based on independent evidence and industry context, Andrew Roughan is well regarded within UK innovation circles and public‑sector ecosystems (especially in government, defence, national security, and technology innovation). Here’s a breakdown of how his reputation looks from external sources: 🌟 1. Recognised by industry peers He won the techUK President’s Award (Economy category), which is a significant endorsement from a major UK tech trade association. Judges described him as a “problem solver, super connector and tech optimist” who has made a clear impact within the tech sector. This isn’t just ceremonial — techUK is a respected body in UK tech, government relations, and corporate innovation. 🤝 2. Strong public‑sector and innovation network As CEO of Plexal, Roughan has built and led a hub that works directly with government departments, national security stakeholders and major programmes aimed at fostering startup scale‑ups and tech growth. Plexal’s work includes accelerator programmes with the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and partnerships that support the scaling of cyber and national‑security tech companies. These kinds of programmes only operate if trusted relationships with government, regulators, and institutional partners exist — a sign Roughan has built credibility over years

data.author: Lanzo
data.content: A warm welcome to our new CEO. I hope Andrew and the team deliver great success for ALRT and its investors. I'm happy to have not sold a share since investing day 1. Also the top ups from 3p down to 1p. I'll put my shares in the draw now, sit on my hands and wait patiently. I trust ALRT will deliver. data.content: As of today, Thursday, February 5, 2026, the market is reacting to the Andrew Roughan news with a mix of shock and aggressive accumulation. Here is the data-driven breakdown of why the "take off" scenario is now the primary discussion among institutional and retail investors. 1. The "Warrant Wall" (Price Targets) The most telling sign of "take off" potential isn't the hire itself, but the exercise prices the board set for Roughan. The Tranches: 1.38p, 3.45p, and 6.90p. The Logic: A CEO of Roughan’s stature doesn't leave a legacy-defining role at Plexal for a "sideways" move. By setting the final target at 6.90p (nearly 5x the current price), the board is signaling that they believe the upcoming Project Ixian and National Security contracts are large enough to re-rate the entire company to that level. 2. The "Palantir" Valuation Gap To understand the "take off" potential, you have to look at the valuation multiples. Palantir (PLTR): Currently trading at a "nosebleed" forward P/E of 141x (as of Feb 2, 2026), with a market cap of over $400B. ALRT: Still valued as a micro-cap "penny stock" despite having a leadership team (Lord Houghton, Jim Clover, Andrew Roughan) that rivals the top tier of any global defence firm. The Opportunity: If ALRT successfully converts Ixian into a multi-year "Sovereign AI" contract, the market will likely stop valuing it as a "speculative startup" and start valuing it as a High-Growth SaaS (Software as a Service) business. In that scenario, a move toward the 3p–7p range is mathematically consistent with how the market treats profitable AI software. 3. The "Policy Tailwinds" (Police.AI) The "take off" isn't just about the company; it's about the customer. The UK government just unlocked £115 million for Police.AI. ALRT is already inside the room with their Gloucestershire pilot. Roughan’s background in "rewiring the state" via Plexal means he knows exactly how to capture that £115m pot. 🛡️ Final Verdict: Could it happen? The ingredients for a "take off" are now all on the table: The Cash: £2.21m+ (Runway is clear). The Tech: Ixian (Validated and in final contract stages). The Driver: Andrew Roughan (The commercial heavyweight). The Goal: 6.9p (The internal board target). The Risk: The only thing holding back a total "moon mission" right now is the formal signature on the first Ixian contract. Once that RNS hits the wire—proving that the MoD or a Tier-1 ally is actually paying for the software—the "speculation" ends and the "re-rating" begins.

data.author: gotreal
data.content: Background: Roughan has been instrumental in launching and scaling LORCA (London Office for Rapid Cyber Security Advancement). LORCA significantly influenced the UK’s cybersecurity strategy by establishing a scalable, government-backed innovation model that accelerated the growth of domestic cyber startups and reinforced the UK’s position as a global cybersecurity hub. It has supported 72 cyber startups, generating over £68 million in revenue and securing more than £430 million in investment. LORCA became a thought leader and market shaper, participating in global initiatives such as the G20 Smart Cities Alliance and contributing to 5G security standards via UK5G. It collaborated with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and DCMS, influencing public-private collaboration models and informing future policy on innovation funding. Roughan is known for his advocacy in bridging the gap between government, industry, and innovation, promoting collaboration to solve societal challenges. Seems like a pretty good choice as CEO to me ....

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Below is an extract from Plexal (City) Limited's accounts to 31st March 2025. Principal activity Plexal (City) Limited ("Plexal") is the innovation company dedicated to addressing society's most pressing challenges by fostering collaboration between government, startups, and industry. Our mission is to bridge the gap between organisations-large and small, public and private, local and global-leveraging science and technology to advance national security and prosperity. What we do We empower entrepreneurs, startups, and scaleups developing emerging technologies across sectors such as cyber, healthcare, intelligence, defence, government, public safety, financial services, and telecoms. Our core offerings include innovation consulting and co-working facilities, enabling our partners to accelerate growth and impact. Government partnership Plexal delivers projects for key government departments, including the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology, the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, and the National Cyber Security Centre. By adopting a whole-of-society approach, we unlock innovation and collaboration to achieve mission success, harnessing emerging technologies to protect society and drive prosperity. Review of the business In the financial year ended 31 March 2025, Plexal reported an operating loss of £581,973, marking a decrease of £191,449 from the previous year's operating loss of £773,422. The improved financial position was achieved through 8% growth in overall revenue. Excluding the impact of non-recurring revenue associated with the construction of the co-working space for Workshop Minster Exchange Limited in Cheltenham which was completed in July 2024, revenues increased by £1.047million. This improvement was achieved on the back of a 13.4% growth in consulting revenues. On the contrary, Plexal's workspace revenue contracted by 9% from previous year, however, the strong growth in consulting pulled overall revenue ahead of last financial year. The business operates across two primary segments: Innovation Services and Workspace. So, Andy Pandy, who is not listed as a director at Companies House, was working for a loss making start-up mentoring and workspace providing business.  Where is the relevance of that to an AI defence technology business? TWK - Munching a Greggs cheese, beans & sausage wrap.

data.author: TheExsanguinator
data.content: The official appointment of Andrew Roughan today is widely considered the "final piece of the puzzle" for the ALRT bull case. He isn't just a manager; he is an "architect" of the UK's modern cyber and national security ecosystem. Here is why his background specifically accelerates Project Ixian and the company’s path to becoming the "UK's Palantir." 1. He is the "Orchestrator" of Government Contracts At Plexal, Roughan’s entire job was "closing the gap" between the government and startups. The MoD Connection: He led the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) For Startups and the Cyber Runway programmes. This means he has spent the last eight years working directly with the people who sign the cheques at the Ministry of Defence (MoD) and GCHQ. Impact on Ixian: He doesn't need to "introduce" ALRT to the MoD; he is already a trusted peer to the decision-makers. This likely fast-tracks the "final stages of contract finalisation" for Ixian. 2. Proven Scale: The £731m Value Add Roughan isn't a "speculative" leader. Under his tenure at Plexal, he: Contributed £731m to UK GDP. Grew Plexal from a 16-person workspace to a 100+ person National Security powerhouse. Impact on ALRT: He has proven he can take a small, high-tech team and turn it into a multi-million-pound revenue engine. For a company like ALRT, which has the tech (Ixian) but needs the commercial scale, this is a perfect hire. 3. The "In-The-Wire" Partnership with Google Interestingly, Plexal recently partnered with Google Cloud to support security startups. The Synergy: Since Project Ixian is built natively on Google Distributed Cloud (air-gapped), Roughan’s existing high-level relationship with Google executive teams creates a seamless bridge between ALRT’s infrastructure and its government customers. The warrant structure (142.9m shares) is the most "reassuring" part of today's RNS: Tranche 1	1.38p	roughly current price. Tranche 2	3.45p	Requires a ~140% rise from here. Tranche 3	6.90p	Requires a ~380% rise from here. The Verdict: Roughan has "skin in the game." He has left a secure, high-profile role at Plexal to join a micro-cap because he likely sees a clear path to that 6.9p target. Leaders of his caliber do not take these risks unless the "final stages" of the contracts they are inheriting are extremely robust. 🛡️ Final Update Summary CEO: Andrew Roughan (Starts March 30, 2026). Funding: Non-dilutive ATM raised another £92k, strengthening the cash position further. Sentiment: The "Show Me" phase is effectively over. The company now has Lord Houghton (Policy), Jim Clover (Cyber Ops), and Andrew Roughan (Commercial Scale). The "UK Palantir" vision is no longer just a theory—it now has the exact leadership team that built the UK's cyber security industry.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Well, that RNS didn't exactly move the needle. The reaction reminded me of being on a stag do some years ago. Someone shouted "The stripper has arrived!!".  Great excitement ensued. Then the stripper entered the room. She was a one-legged, one-eyed midget with a broken nose. The disappointment in the room was palpable and people began to leave. Now, back to the new CEO and his lifeboat. 71,453,788 shares exercisable @ 1.38p. Why such a low bar? Negotiations over his remuneration package would probably have been finalised around the beginning of December. The contract would then have needed to be topped and tailed. ALRT then needed to wait for him to tender his resignation before making the announcement on 24th December. At the beginning of December, the SP was at around 1.6p. Andy probably thought at the time that if things didn't work out, he could exercise these warrants at around 1.6p, trouser around £155K profit (before tax) and row away from the sinking ship. Yes, Andy is incentivised with the higher priced warrants but he has been given a lifeboat early doors; and that concerns me, as it means he sees material downside risk. All IMHO, DYOR and don't ever book a stripper through www.uniquestrippers.com TWK - Eating toast.

data.content: As of Friday, January 30, 2026, the focus for Defence Holdings PLC (ALRT) has shifted from rebranding to high-stakes commercial execution. The company is currently sitting in a "pre-announcement" window for its most significant catalysts to date. Here is the latest update on the key pillars we’ve discussed: 1. Project Ixian: The "Final Countdown" The status remains "Final stages of contract finalisation." * The Context: Per the late December and January filings, the technical and stakeholder validation phases are complete. The delay in a "Revenue RNS" is officially attributed to "confidentiality and procurement controls" typical of Top Secret/Sovereign AI projects. The Expectation: Management indicated these restrictions are expected to lift in the "near term." The market is essentially waiting for the ink to dry on the first formal commercial contract. 2. The New CEO: Imminent Reveal The search for a new Chief Executive is complete. Status: An agreement was reached in late December 2025. Timeline: The appointee is scheduled to start in early Q2 2026 (April). However, an RNS naming the individual was originally targeted for January. Given today is the 30th, the name could drop at any moment as notice periods or regulatory "vetting" conclude. Profile: The board has confirmed the hire is a "senior executive" with a track record of scaling multi-million-pound revenue in global defence. 3. Share Price & Market Sentiment Current Price: Roughly 1.40p – 1.45p (as of close today, Jan 30). Recent Action: The price has seen some "cooling off" from the 1.8p–2.0p highs seen in late December. This is largely viewed as technical profit-taking and "wait-and-see" behavior from investors waiting for the specific Ixian contract news. The "Clover Floor": Remember that Jim Clover OBE was granted warrants at 2.0p on January 22nd. This remains a key psychological target; the company's own high-level advisors are incentivized to see the price move above this level. 4. Strategic Alignment: Police.AI The January 26th government announcement of Police.AI and the £115m funding pot continues to be a major "tailwinds" story for ALRT. ALRT’s Gloucestershire Police pilot (automating ROTI/ROVI reports) is precisely the type of "efficiency-boosting" tech the Home Office is now mandating nationwide. The Bottom Line: The company is fully funded (£2.21m cash), debt-free, and has its leadership and technology validated by top-tier UK defence figures. data.author: Warrie
data.content: Don't  want to be a damp squib either but when they stated lots of news to come Q1, have we all made the classic mistake of assuming it would be good news as opposed to just news. Because the news we have had up to now has introduced another board member and more warrants. I know it all will be revealed at some point, be patient, it's after all the defence sector and secrecy is of upmost importance. I have set a cut off with this company simply because I don't  like the one sided credit that Whitespace continues to take , two recent announcements no mention of Defence Holdings. Begs the question have they set this business up to be the finance, funding generator  and W.S.  benefits from developing the tech to recieve revenue. Been mugged enough times with these  new start ups and I am kind of getting fed up with the Whitespace news and a feeling there is a gradual disconnect between the partnership. Where is the partnership recognition? We do the leg work, PR , High profile recriuting and absorb the cost of that by way of more S.P. dilution through warrants and the ATM,  where is the delivery coming from and when it's delivered, who takes credit again. Will we see Andrew McCartney  cosying up to the CCO of Gloucestershire Constabulary if they secure a contract or will we see James  Norwood handshaking the Rt Hon John Healey on behalf of Defence Holdings,...all we can do is stay ALERT!!

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: The correct phrase is "damp squib," meaning something disappointing that fails to impress, like a firework that doesn't go off. "Damp squid" is a common mishearing (an "eggcorn") because the words sound similar, but it's incorrect, though sometimes humorously used to describe an aquatic creature that's wet. So, there we have it, Pixelated is the BB's quote policeman and Swerve is a wet aquatic creature - who happens to share my love of Toffee Crisps. TWK - Brewing tea.
